column4: German: [ˈdaʁmʃtat] (listen)) is a city in the state of Hesse in Germany
column5: located in the southern part of the Rhine-Main-Area (Frankfurt Metropolitan Region). Darmstadt had a population of around 157
column6: 437 at the end of 2016. The Darmstadt Larger Urban Zone has 430
column7: 993 inhabitants.Darmstadt holds the official title "City of Science" (German: Wissenschaftsstadt) as it is a major centre of scientific institutions
column9: and high-technology companies. The European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites (EUMETSAT) and the European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) are located in Darmstadt
column10: as well as GSI Centre for Heavy Ion Research
column11: where several chemical elements such as bohrium (1981)
column16: and copernicium (1996) were discovered. The existence of the following elements were also confirmed at GSI Centre for Heavy Ion Research: nihonium (2012)

column22: which is the city's largest employer.

column1: Darmstadt was formerly the capital of a sovereign country
column2: the Grand Duchy of Hesse and its successor
column3: the People's State of Hesse
column4: a federal state of Germany. As the capital of an increasingly prosperous duchy

column8: and are still a major part of the city's economy. It is also home to the football club SV Darmstadt 98. Alexandra Feodorovna of Russia

column1: The name Darmstadt first appears towards the end of the 11th century
column2: then as Darmundestat. Its origins are unknown. 'Dar-mund' in Middle Low German is translated as "Boggy Headlands"
column3: but it could be a misspelling in local dialect of another name. It is sometimes stated that the name derives from the 'Darmbach' (a small stream formerly running through the city). In fact
column4: the stream received its current name much later
column5: after the city
column6: not vice versa.Darmstadt was chartered as a city by the Holy Roman Emperor Ludwig the Bavarian in 1330
column7: at which time it belonged to the counts of Katzenelnbogen. The city
column9: became a secondary residence for the counts
column10: with a small castle established at the site of the current
column11: much larger edifice.When the house of Katzenelnbogen became extinct in 1479
column12: the city was passed to the Landgraviate of Hesse
column13: and was seat of the ruling landgraves (1567–1806) and thereafter (to 1918) of the grand dukes of Hesse.

column10: first synthesised the chemical MDMA (ecstasy) in Darmstadt. Darmstadt's municipal area was extended in 1937 to include the neighbouring localities of Arheilgen and Eberstadt
column11: and in 1938 the city was separated administratively from the surrounding district (Kreis).

column1: Darmstadt was the first city in Germany to force Jewish shops to close in early 1933
column2: shortly after the Nazis took power in Germany. The shops were only closed for one day
column3: for "endangering communal order and tranquility". In 1942
column4: over 3
column5: 000 Jews from Darmstadt were first forced into a collection camp located in the Liebigschule
column6: and later deported to concentration camps where most eventually died.

column1: Several prominent members of the German resistance movement against the Nazis were citizens of Darmstadt
column2: including Wilhelm Leuschner and Theodor Haubach
column3: both executed for their opposition to Hitler's regime.

column1: Darmstadt was first bombed on 30 July 1940
column2: and 34 other air raids would follow before the war's end. The old city centre was largely destroyed in a British bombing raid on 11 September 1944. This attack was an example of the firestorm technique
column3: which was subsequently used against the historic city of Dresden in February 1945. To create a firestorm
column4: a number of explosive blast bombs are dropped around the city before the incendiary bombs are dropped
column5: thus beginning a self-sustaining combustion process in which winds generated by the fire ensure it continues to burn until everything possible has been consumed. Darmstadt was selected as the secondary target for the raid
column6: but was promoted to the primary target after clouds were observed over the primary which would have hindered any reconnaissance of the after-effects. During this fire attack an estimated 11
column8: 500 of the inhabitants burned to death
column11: 000 were left homeless. Over three-quarters of Darmstadt's inner city was destroyed. Post-war rebuilding was done in a relatively plain architectural style
column12: although a number of the historic buildings were rebuilt to their original appearance following the city's capture on 20 March 1945 by the American 4th Armored Division.

column14: finally University of Applied sciences emerged as a separate industry based research educational institution in 1971 and is the largest University of Applied Sciences in Hesse (German: Hessen) with about 11

Darmstadt is highly connected to all means of transportation
column3: the Intercity-Express Network and a major international airport.

column1: Darmstadt is connected to a number of major roads
column2: including two Autobahnen (Bundesautobahn 5 and Bundesautobahn 67). The main road passing west–east is the Bundesstraße 26
column3: the Bundesstraße 3 runs north–south. The rural areas east of the city in the Odenwald are accessed by several secondary roads.

column1: The extensive public transport system of Darmstadt is integrated in the RMV (the transportation authority of the Frankfurt Metropolitan Area). The backbone of public transport in Darmstadt is its modern tram system with 9 lines and a local bus service serving all parts of the city. Darmstadt is furthermore connected to the Frankfurt S-Bahn system and being served by regional bus lines. Furthermore
column4: R66) connect six secondary railway stations within the city.

column1: Darmstadt is connected to the Frankfurt rapid transit network by S-Bahn line S3. Besides that
column2: a number of regional trains connect secondary railway stations within Darmstadt and the region with Darmstadt Hauptbahnhof (main station)
column3: offering a net of inner city and regional train links.

column1: By its main railway station "Darmstadt Hauptbahnhof"
column2: which is located in the western part of the central city
column3: Darmstadt is connected to the rest of Germany and Europe by the Intercity-Express network and other long-distance trains. Darmstadt Hauptbahnhof is a busy station with 12 platforms which serves as a transportation hub for the southern Hesse/Odenwald region.

column1: Frankfurt International AirportDarmstadt can be easily accessed from around the world via Frankfurt Airport (Flughafen Frankfurt am Main) which is located 20 km (12 mi) north of central Darmstadt and connected to it via Autobahn 5
column3: several bus lines and a direct express bus-link ("Airliner"). The airport ranks among the world's busiest airports by passenger traffic and is the second-busiest airport by cargo traffic in Europe. The airport also serves as the main hub for German flag carrier Lufthansa.

column1: Frankfurt Egelsbach AirportFrankfurt Egelsbach Airport (Flugplatz Frankfurt-Egelsbach) is a busy general aviation airport located 5 km north of Darmstadt

column2: Frankfurt Hahn Airport (Flughafen Frankfurt-Hahn) is located far outside the Frankfurt Metro Area
column3: approximately 120 km (75 mi) to the west in Lautzenhausen (Rhineland-Palatinate). Hahn Airport is a major base for low-cost carrier Ryanair. This airport can only be reached by car or bus.

column1: Darmstadt is served by several national and European bus links which connect Darmstadt with other German and European cities.

column3: and attractions ==

column1: Darmstadt was the capital of an independent country (the Grand Duchy of Hesse) until 1871 and the capital of the German state of Hesse until 1945. It is due to its past as a capital city that it has many architectural testimonies of this period. Many of its major architectural landmarks were created by Georg Moller who was appointed the court master builder of the Grand Duchy of Hesse. Due to the fact that the last ruling Grand Duke of Hesse
column2: Ernst Ludwig was a grandson of Queen Victoria and brother to Empress Alexandra of Russia
column3: the architecture of Darmstadt has been influenced by British and Russian imperial architecture with many examples still existing
column4: such as the Luisenplatz with its grand-ducal column
column5: the old Hessian State Theatre (at Karolinenplatz) and the Russian Chapel by Leon Benois. The Russian church
column7: is named in honor of the patron saint of Tsar Nicholas' mother and was built of Russian stone on Russian soil brought to Darmstadt by train. It was used by the Russian imperial family and court during regular visits to the Tsarina's brother and family in Darmstadt. The grand-ducal palace of Darmstadt is located in the city centre. It was the residence of the counts of Hesse-Darmstadt
column8: later as Grand Dukes of Hesse by the grace of Napoleon. The rulers of Hesse also owned Jagdschloss Kranichstein
column9: a hunting lodge in Kranichstein which is a nowadays used as a five star hotel. The most famous castle in the Darmstadt region is Frankenstein Castle due to claims that the real castle may have had an influence on Mary Shelley's decision to choose the name Frankenstein for her monster-creating scientist. This castle dates back to the 13th century
column10: but it was acquired by the counts of Hesse-Darmstadt in 1662.

column1: Darmstadt has a rich tradition in modern architecture. After 1945 several "Meisterbauten" (Masterful Architectonic Creations) were built that set standards for modern architecture. These buildings still exist and are used for various public and private purposes. In the late 1990s the Waldspirale ('Forest Spiral') was built
column2: a residential complex by Austrian Friedensreich Hundertwasser. As an almost surreal building
column3: it is internationally famous for its almost absolute rejection of rectangular forms
column4: down to every window having a different shape
column5: the style being a trademark of Hundertwasser's work. Hundertwasser died before the Waldspirale was finished.

column1: Darmstadt was a centre of the Art Nouveau movement. Surviving examples of the Jugendstil period include the Rosenhöhe
column2: a landscaped English-style rose garden from the 19th century
column3: recently renovated and replanted
column4: the Mathildenhöhe
column5: with the Hochzeitsturm ('Wedding tower'
column6: also commonly known as the 'Five-Finger-Tower') by Joseph Maria Olbrich
column7: the Russian Chapel in Darmstadt and large exhibition halls as well as many private villas built by Jugendstil architects who had settled in Darmstadt. German Art Nouveau is commonly known by its German name
column8: Jugendstil. The name is taken from the artistic journal
column10: which was published in Munich and which espoused the new artistic movement. It was founded in 1896 by Georg Hirth (Hirth remained editor until his death in 1916
column11: and the magazine continued to be published until 1940). The magazine was instrumental in promoting the style in Germany. As a result
column12: its name was adopted as the most common German-language term for the style: Jugendstil ("young style"). Although
column14: the word was applied to only two-dimensional examples of the graphic arts
column15: especially the forms of organic typography and graphic design found in and influenced by German magazines like Jugend
column18: it is now applied to more general manifestations of Art Nouveau visual arts in Germany
column21: and Nordic countries. The two main centres for Jugendstil art in Germany were Munich and Darmstadt.

column2: the central square of the city
column3: forms the centre of the city and is the main public transport hub. In 1844 the Ludwigsäule (called Langer Lui
column4: meaning Long Ludwig)
column5: a 33-metre (108 ft) column commemorating Ludwig I
column7: was placed in the middle of the square. While the column still stands
column8: the square is today surrounded by mostly modern buildings. Other important squares are the Marktplatz (see image) near the old city hall and the Sabaisplatz at the Mathildenhöhe.

column1: The city has a high density of parks. Among the most important parks are the English style Herrngarten in central Darmstadt. In former times it was part of the Royal Gardens used exclusively by the dukes of Darmstadt. Today it is a public park
column2: heavily used in every season of the year. Other important parks are the French style parks Prinz-Georgs-Garten and Orangerie
column3: the modern style Bürgerpark ("People's Park") in northern Darmstadt and the mystical Park Rosenhöhe
column4: ("Rose Heights") which also serves as the cemetery for the dukes
column5: with two impressive mausoleum buildings in its remote parts. The Botanischer Garten in eastern Darmstadt is a botanical garden maintained by the Technische Universität Darmstadt with a fine collection of rare plants and trees.

column3: is in the pedestrian zone of the downtown city center
column4: next to the historic Hotel Bockshaut. The church has gothic elements along with renaissance and baroque
column5: it houses the royal crypt. Hotel Bockshaut was built in 1580 for a church presbytery. The most important Catholic Church is St. Ludwig in central Darmstadt. The Russian Chapel in Darmstadt is a Russian orthodox church which is still in use. It was built and used as a private chapel by the last Tsar of Russia
column7: whose wife Alexandra was born in Darmstadt. Although Russian orthodox churches also exist in other cities outside Russia
column8: the Russian Chapel in Darmstadt was the only official Russian church used by the Tsar outside the Russian Empire. It is said that the chapel was built on Russian soil that was brought to Darmstadt exclusively for the purpose of building the Tsar's private chapel on it.

column1: Every year on the first weekend of July the Heinerfest festival is held in the streets surrounding the old ducal palace. It is a traditional German festival with music acts
column3: amusement rides and booths selling trinkets and food. The similar 'Schloßgrabenfest'
column4: which is more live music-oriented
column5: is held in the same location every year in May. These two festivals attract 700

column1: Darmstadt has a rich cultural heritage. The Staatstheater Darmstadt (State Theatre Darmstadt) dates back to the year 1711. The present building has been in use since 1972 and has three halls which can be used independently. The "Grand Hall" (Großes Haus) provides seats for 956 people and serves as Darmstadt's opera house. The "Small Hall" (Kleines Haus) is mostly used for plays and dance and has 482 seats. A separate small hall (Kammerspiele) with 120 seats is used for chamber plays.
Among the museums in Darmstadt the most important are the Hessisches Landesmuseum (Hessian State Museum)
column2: the Porcelain Museum (exhibition of the ducal porcelain)
column3: the Schlossmuseum (exhibition of the ducal residence and possessions)
column4: the Kunsthalle Darmstadt (exhibitions of modern art)
column5: the exhibition centre Mathildenhöhe and the Museum Künstlerkolonie (Art Nouveau museum).

column1: The Jazz-Institut Darmstadt is Germany's largest publicly accessible jazz archive.The Internationales Musikinstitut Darmstadt
column2: harboring one of the world's largest collections of post-war sheet music
column3: also hosts the biennial Internationale Ferienkurse für Neue Musik
column4: a summer school in contemporary classical music founded by Wolfgang Steinecke. A large number of avant-garde composers have attended and given lectures there
column5: including Olivier Messiaen

column1: The Deutsche Akademie für Sprache und Dichtung provides writers and scholars with a place to research the German language. The Academy's annual Georg Büchner Prize
column2: named in memory of Georg Büchner
column3: is considered the most prestigious literary award for writers of German language.

column1: Darmstadt is located in the Upper Rhine Plain (German: Oberrheinische Tiefebene)
column3: about 350 km (217 mi) long and on average 50 km (31 mi) wde
column4: between the cities of Frankfurt in the north and Basel in the south. Darmstadt's southeastern boroughs are located in the spurs of the Odenwald
column5: a low mountain range in Southern Hesse between the Main and Neckar rivers.

column1: Southern Hesse is well known for its mild climate which allows winegrowing on a large scale in the region south of Darmstadt. The weather is often volatile with the summers being warm and humid with frequent thunderstorms
column2: the winters mostly relatively mild with frequent periods of high fog. Snowfall is most likely in January and February
column3: but mild winters without considerable snowfall can occur.

column1: The City of Darmstadt offers students a broad variety of public primary
column2: secondary and tertiary schools. Besides them private schools exist
column3: e.g. the catholic secondary school Edith-Stein-Schule
column4: the Adventists' Schulzentrum Marienhöhe
column5: an anthroposophic Waldorf School
column6: a Comenius School and other faith based private schools.

column1: Darmstadt University of Applied Sciences (German: Hochschule Darmstadt) has the highest number of industrial linkage programs
column2: compared to the rest of the universities of applied sciences. The roots of University of Applied Sciences Darmstadt dates back to 1876. However
column3: it has not emerged as a separate institution before 1971. Today (2017) it is the largest University of Applied Sciences in the State of Hesse with about 16
column4: 000 students offering courses in architecture
column5: chemical engineering

column1: Technical University of Darmstadt (German: Technische Universität Darmstadt)
column2: commonly referred to as TU Darmstadt
column3: is a prestigious research university in Germany. It was founded in 1877 and received the right to award doctorates in 1899. In 1882 it was the first university in the world to set up a chair in electrical engineering
column4: in 1883 the first faculty for electrical engineering was founded there. The University is organized in 13 departments and 5 fields of study
column5: which all together offer about 100 courses of studies. The fields of study offer interdisciplinary degree courses in which students take lectures in multiple departments. The University
column7: offers degree courses in the fields of electrical
column11: mathematics and the natural sciences. It also offers courses in economics
column17: sport science and linguistics. It also offers degree courses for teaching positions at German vocational schools and Gymnasiums.

column1: The Protestant University of Applied Sciences Darmstadt (EHD) is an officially recognised and Church-sponsored University. The sponsors are the Protestant Church in Hesse and Nassau
column2: the Protestant Church of Kurhesse-Waldeck and the social welfare organisation of both Hessian Protestant Churches
column3: the Diakonie Hesse. The EHD has approximately 1
column4: 700 students
column5: 40 professors and 10 scientific employees and about 100 visiting lecturers every semester.

column1: Darmstadt is home to many research institutions such as the Fraunhofer Society (Fraunhofer IGD
column3: Fraunhofer SIT) and the Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI
column4: "Society for heavy ion Research")
column5: which operates a particle accelerator in northern Darmstadt. The GSI
column7: discovered the chemical element darmstadtium (atomic number: 110)
column8: named after the city in 2003. This makes Darmstadt one of only eight settlements with elements named after them (the others being Ytterby in Sweden (four elements); Stockholm in Sweden (holmium); Strontian in Scotland; Copenhagen in Denmark (whose Latin name gives hafnium); Paris (whose Latin name gives lutetium); Berkeley
column9: California; and Dubna in Russia). Various other elements
column12: roentgenium (atomic number: 111) (1994) and copernicium (atomic number: 112) (1996) were also synthesized in the Darmstadt facility.

column1: The European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) of the European Space Agency is located in Darmstadt. From here

column1: Darmstadt is a centre for the pharmaceutical and chemical industry

column1: U.S. forces entered the city of Darmstadt on 25 March 1945. At the end of World War II
column2: Darmstadt was among the 112 communities where U.S. forces were stationed. Early units stationed here included elements of the U.S. Constabulary
column3: Air Force units and a Quartermaster School.

column2: the U.S. military community Darmstadt – under a variety of designations – served as home for thousands of American soldiers and their families. It included six principal installations in Darmstadt and nearby Babenhausen
column3: Griesheim and Münster
column4: plus several housing areas
column5: an airfield and a large number of smaller facilities as far away as Bensheim and Aschaffenburg. The military newspaper European Stars and Stripes also had its headquarters there. As of 1993
column6: the Darmstadt military community also assumed responsibility for the remaining U.S. Army facilities in the Frankfurt area.
